title: Before 1 January 2018, will the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration grant a waiver allowing Amazon to test its unmanned aerial vehicles?
preds: UAVs are the future of civilian aerospace

The US government is technologically clueless, therefore a slave to special interests. The advice they take regarding cyberpolicy is all coming from the tech giants who do, and will continue to rule a corporate owned internet. Cluelessness at the highest level was demonstrated by Jeff Sessions at Senate Committee hearings, proving that, arguably, the White House's top "performer" knows nothing. That means our whole government is putting our security, therefore our national security in the hands of these tech giants. From an old hacker's perspective, my own, I'd interpret Russia's actions, including all election tampering, as an exercise and a dare. It is a dare to see if the Americans are still taking the world seriously. And, the Russians encourage hacking rather than prosecuting people for dissent just for speaking about it. And hacking is a very broad field, a science of reverse engineering. In Russia, they know the difference between hacking and social engineering. It is absolutely vital for all Americans to understand this difference moving forward.
Maintaining forecast; no recent news from Amazon on testing in the U.S. Current reports involve patenting or testing in the U.K.
No urgency with little time remaining.
These questions I am going with consensus. Just tracking HFC

There are rumours that Nevada State will partner with Amazon in the FAA pilot program: http://www.rgj.com/story/money/business/2017/11/28/amazon-hq-2-nevada-skies-drones-faa-pilot-program/902286001/
Even if the rumours turn out to be true, the “Interested Parties must submit a request by 2.00pm ET, December 13, 2017” 
Then, “By 2.00pm ET, January 4, 2018: Lead applicants complete volumes III, IV, V and VI, in the application portal” (https://www.faa.gov/uas/programs_partnerships/uas_integration_pilot_program/) 
Which suggests a waiver will not be granted between now and 1 January 2018.
Waivers will be granted but not yet this year with holidays upon us.
Not much time left, disappointing but I don't think this will happen this year.

Amazon's Dream of Drone Deliveries Get Closer With Trump's Executive Order
Trump’s order says Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao will approve at least five applications from local governments within six months.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-25/amazon-s-dream-of-drone-deliveries-get-closer-with-trump-order It absolutely does not, though it may happen next year.
Seems like a good idea, but bureaucracies are notoriously slow to make decisions.

Dropped from 75 to 0. Optimistic. Drone was just R&D and marketing stunt. Great PR!  The new Key service has nullified the need for drone. Delivery vans are already driving around anyway, so can now complete much more deliveries if people are crazy enough to risk theft or losing their pets with this insane Key service.
Due to the introduction of the  UAS Integration Pilot Program, it's unlikely that the FAA will use a waiver to allow Amazon to test, opting for allowing Amazon to become part of the program instead.

They should be able to make an application to fly within 5 miles of an airport without requesting a waiver per the LAANC program: https://www.faa.gov/uas/programs_partnerships/uas_data_exchange/airports_participating_in_laanc/ If Amazon wants to go farther than that, it needs to make another kind of application. But still no idea if Amazon has applied for a waiver.
Dropping more points because the federal government seems more focused on the 19th century.

Lowering forecast; after looking through the details of the executive order, I think its unlikely a waiver will be granted in the time period that remains on this forecast.  “Within 90 days of the date of this memorandum, the Secretary of Transport, in consultation with the Administration of the FAA shall establish a UAS Integration Pilot Program”  “Within 180 days of the establishment of the program, the secretary shall enter into agreements with state, local or tribal government to participate in the program, with the goal of entering into at least 5 such agreements by that time”
(https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2017-23746.pdf)

White House is planning to announce federal/local agreement to expand use of unmanned aerial drones.  I believe that Amazon may likely be granted such a waiver to conduct testing. Whether this occurs before Jan 1, 2018 remains unclear and will depend on the actual process to be set forth. https://www.wsj.com/articles/white-house-to-test-federal-local-sharing-of-drone-regulation-1508320807
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
I think Amazon meg be going a different way.

The FAA is requesting “Emergency Clearance to Revise Information Collection 2120-0768, Part 107 Authorisations and Waivers” 
“The FAA is seeking to implement the Low Altitude Authorisation and Notification Capability (LAANC) system.”
“FAA is requesting OMB approval of this collection of information 7 days after publication of this Notice in the Federal Register. Upon OMB approval of its Emergency clearance request, FAA will follow the normal clearance procedures for the information collection associated with LAANC” 
(https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/10/11/2017-21878/request-for-emergency-processing-of-collection-of-information-by-the-office-of-management-and-budget) 
The LAANC will improve the safety of drones flying in controlled airspace, however I don’t think that this implementation will have an impact on Amazon’s UAV testing by the end of the year. Reports are that the prototype of this system will be up by the end of the year. https://www.expouav.com/news/latest/perfect-union-us-regulations-trend-toward-coexistence-uavs-aircraft/  Meanwhile, Amazon may be planning to have its own delivery service: http://fortune.com/2017/10/05/amazon-delivery-service-ups-fedex/
Dropping a bit because this really should have happened by now.

Lowering forecast: Amazon’s Vice President of innovation policy, Paul Misener, said “We’re designing a fleet of highly autonomous drones to the point of being automated vehicles and the whole idea is that they need to know where to go and what to do if there’s a problem.” (https://www.retail-week.com/topics/technology/amazons-innovation-boss-on-building-autonomous-drones/7025959.article) 
The fact that these drones are still in the design stage suggests that they are still being developed to fly safely, therefore, they may not necessarily reach the FAA standards to grant a waiver.  Meanwhile, Matternet has secured a special license from the Swiss Federal Office of Civil Aviation to operate an autonomous drone network, “shuttling blood and other medical samples between hospitals and testing facilities.” (https://www.wired.com/story/switzerlands-getting-a-delivery-network-for-blood-toting-drones/). They have also partnered with Mercedes Benz and Siroop to deliver packages in Zurich - https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/delivery-by-drone-switzerland-tests-it-in-populated-areas/2017/09/28/27cc04c2-a48a-11e7-b573-8ec86cdfe1ed_story.html?utm_term=.04eaecf1e31e
Matternet is also an American company, like Amazon, that has chosen to test its products abroad rather than in the U.S., which suggests the FAA policies are not aligned for testing drone delivery at the current moment.

- There are only 3 months until 2018; 13 months have elapsed since regulation
 - Drone-blackhawk strike may slow approvals (too early to see an impact on approval rate)
 - Consensus is much higher probability - 30%

Drone deliveries seems to have reached the point where it could be done, but the legal issues (routing, privacy, fail safe) remain difficult and the practical issues (how much can a drone carry, how much will a drone delivery cost vs conventional deliver, how can the goods be placed in a secure place) are not favourable.
drone hit a blackhawk - not likely
Blackhawk just hit a drone in NYC airspace.  Nothing will be approved until after an investigation.   http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/09/22/drone-hits-army-helicopter/

If the US want to Keep ahead of Technology then they Need to react soon.

Dropping significantly because the FAA is still meandering toward UAV rules.

Maintaining for now:  It could be that because Amazon hasn’t partnered with the FAA, they are at a disadvantage when it comes to proving safety in order to receive a waiver. “This Summer, PrecisionHawk asked Applied Aviation Research Centre to participate in phase three of the FAA Pathfinder program which involves testing the reliability of technological aids when flying BVLOS, and aims to provide operational risk assessment to the FAA to help further define safety regulations for operating a UAV in commercial airspace.”
Andi Mayer, research program manager at AARC said: “Technological aids are needed for such operations, but they still need validation and reliability testing before the industry can move forward. This field testing provides data for PrecisionHawk’s operational risk assessment that is a critical piece of the regulatory approval process.” 
“AARC and PrecisionHawk collaborated in Summer 2016 on field experiments to observe pilots’ decision making when flying in extended VLOS (EVLOS). As a result of the collaboration, PrecisionHawk was able to attain the only EVLOS waiver in the nation from the FAA for commercial UAV operations” (http://www.feedstuffs.com/news/applied-aviation-research-center-precisionhawk-continue-uas-collaboration)
“From the part 107 waiver PrecisionHawk can fly drones BVLOS during its commercial operations. Also under the waiver, PrecisionHawk is approved to train those who want to offer these EVLOS flights as a service. The waiver was granted based on over a years worth of testing under the pathfinder program” (http://www.precisionhawk.com/media/topic/faa-grants-precisionhawk-bvlos-waiver/)

“Phase three is the final phase of the FAA Pathfinder program, all results are provided to the FAA for consideration upon completion of field tests” 
(http://www.feedstuffs.com/news/applied-aviation-research-center-precisionhawk-continue-uas-collaboration) Will adjust forecast when PrecisionHawk announces the results. If the results yield valuable information which is encouraging to the FAA in terms of incorporating UAVs into commercial airspace, they may be more willing to approve Part 107 waivers for commercial operations - however, there is a time limitation of just over 4 months.

No particular reason for them not to do this, except that in the current atmosphere most US agencies, even those headed by appointees with fixed terms, are full of people who are diligently pretending to be dead.
Lowered due to time, lack of finding sources, other forecasters dipping their %s, and the FAA privatization will take up a lot of time/energy/resources.

Amazon has continued applying for drone delivery patents, but there seems to be no news on applying to test drones in the US. This possibly indicates that the testing outside the US that Amazon has been doing has reached a point where the technical issues of picking up a package and flying to a deliver address has been achieved but the issues of how to regulate drone deliveries (allocation of air space, privacy, public nuisance etc.) have not, therefore they have nothing new to test.

Decreasing my estimate due to public criticism of amazon by the american president. I also feel that 5 months is a relatively short time frame for a bureaucratic organisation like the FAA to change policy.
The use of drones is becoming more common, but bureaucratic inertia will slow down rule making. Federal Register rulemaking is a time consumi by process.
Dropping 20 points and going to continue dropping on this question because I just don't see the FAA moving quickly to approve this waiver.

Amazon has patented “trigger agents in video streams from drones”: “In the context of this specification, unmanned aerial vehicles may be configured with data capturing devices for capturing data while delivering an item as permitted”. (http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=20&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=%22Amazon+Technologies%22&OS=%22Amazon+Technologies%22&RS=%22Amazon+Technologies%22)  With surveillance being a controversial subject it’s possible there will be backlash to Amazon’s drones collecting data on properties whilst delivering packages. Whilst the FAA is responsible for the skies it will come down to the laws set in each State.
I continue to think this unlikely. This administration would not allow the Bezo's Amazon to receive a waiver.
There seems to be a lack of interest on all sides as other matters dominate the news cycles.

Pretty slim chance. Bezos has a lot on his plate--growth of Echo related devices, Amazon Flex, and the purchase of Whole Foods. They can certainly do multiple thing at once, and do them well, it just seems to me that this will require more than excellence and focus to get it done.
Seems that Amazon's focus is currently solely on testing outside the US.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

The government is understandably nervous about regulating drone delivery services. On May 31st at a Drone Conference, Elaine Chow (Secretary of Transportation) preached the need for Sillicon Valley firms to share with the public their understanding of their own products, as well as the safety and privacy concerns regarding drones. She also spoke about how the FAA is currently undertaking studies in order to determine the parameters for safe drone flight over people, and admitted that it has been a labor intensive and occasionally frustrating process. Couple this concern over safety/privacy, the fact that the regulation is still squarely in the "research and study" phase, and the relative paralysis of the entire government due to so much political capital being wrapped up in healthcare and the growing Russia scandal, I give a 20% likelihood that Amazon will receive a waiver before January 1st 2018. The only reason I give them such a chance is because of their lobbying power and the single minded will of Jeff Bezos to quickly and decisively move into new areas of opportunity for Amazon.

FAA Safety requirements for UAV waiver: https://www.faa.gov/uas/request_waiver/waiver_safety_explanation_guidelines/
I'm not sure whether Amazon will meet the safety requirements, as this depends on how much testing they've done at their facilities. 
Rules such as: §107.35: Operation of multiple small unmanned aircraft systems, requires the applicant to "Provide a method to resolve failure of single and multiple aircraft or systems simultaneously." 
At their test site in Cambridge, UK, only one drone was operated autonomously, it is possible that they've tested multiple drones simultaneously at their private sites. 
Legislation passed by a House Panel approved Rep. Bill Shuster's legislation that would set rules for drone delivery, beyond -line-of-sight operations, and agreeing on a unified air traffic management system. 
The bill calls for: 
• "The secretary of transportation to decide within 120 days whether or not air traffic management systems are a viable choice for the problem at hand."
• "The FAA to allow flights farther than the pilot can see within six months at six testing regions nationwide."  Note: the FAA has already been testing flights called beyond line of sight with BNSF Railway.
(https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/06/27/drones-would-get-rules-deliveries-traffic-management-under-house-bill/428836001/)  Maintaining current forecast: despite positive development with regulations in the form of the House Bill, the FAA's Waiver Safety Explanation Guidelines would make it hard for Amazon to get a waiver within 6 months (though I do understand the developments in drone operations is kept confidential, so they could be more advanced than I think).
Lowering as time passes and no visible progress.

Loath as I am to say this, I do not believe that governance will get in the way of politics for the rest of the calendar year, though there is a slim chance that a whiff of normal order may be revived once the next fiscal year begins.
I believe Tetbury and others are correct. But, I'll put my forecast lower than theirs at this point.
I am taking notice of other forecasters arguments (radical idea?)
Updating for the passage of time.

Lowering forecast: Thanks @Tetbury for the article! Although the Reauthorisation of the FAA Summary shows a step towards improving drone regulations for Amazon to conduct testing in the future, there are a couple of subjects that I would expect the FAA has to focus on before they can get on to “Drone Package Delivery” and “Opportunities for Innovation”. 
The two subjects - “Drone Safety Features” and as @shsmith330 said “Privacy Protections” - would have to go through research and evaluation procedures before Amazon could be considered for testing automated drone flights.  Bearing in mind the “FAA Reauthorization Act of 2017” reauthorises the FAA through to 2021 - I would expect it to take at least a year for FAA regulation to be implemented from the date the targets are laid out.
An example of the timeline for a subject matter being brought to the attention of the FAA and the date of implementing new regulation is pilot fatigue. In 2009 the DOT identified pilot fatigue as a top priority after a commercial airliner crashed (killing 50 people), by September 10, 2010 the FAA had created a new pilot flight, duty and rest proposal. This regulation took a year to implement, and would’ve been acted on effectively considering the circumstances - which leads me to think it could be longer than a year before drone regulation is at the point of drone delivery.

There are reasons why the US might be behind with testing delivery drones:-
Property owners rights over their land
A wish to protect delivery drivers jobs
For Amazon Trump might have personal reasons for not helping to change the regulations But at some point surely the US will decide it does not want to permanently left behind in this field and will become more drone friendly. If the US does not want to lead, then other countries will be happy to continue to provide facilities. 
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-22/amazon-vision-of-deliveries-by-drone-gets-boost-in-faa-measure

Property rights in the US are more citizen friendly than the countries currently allowing drone delivery testing by Amazon.  In 1946, Causby vs. US ruled a specific number of at least 365 feet above the property owner's domain belongs to the property owner.  Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon, is also considered a California liberal and the current Presidential administration has shown a penchant for spiteful behavior towards any opposition.  The FAA is managed by the executive branch of the US government and President Trump is the boss. I predict this issue will drag out for another year or two.    http://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21723000-engineers-and-regulators-will-have-work-together-ensure-safety-drones-take
 https://www.amazon.com/Amazon-Prime-Air/b?node=8037720011
 https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/328/256/case.html

We could use Matternet as a possible marker as to when Amazon would get a waiver. The premise of both Amazon and Matternet’s operations are similar in terms of automated flights being conducted BVLOS: Matternet have tested their drones in New Guinea, Malawi and Switzerland. “It claimed the distinction of being the first in the world to be authorized to conduct drone deliveries beyond line of sight over populated areas, specifically the Swiss community of Lugano, home to about 50,000 residents.” 
“Their drones fly at low altitudes, 400 feet and below, generally along predefined routes connecting two points. A parachute is primed to deploy if the system detects a failure or anomaly that could bring the drone down, to ensure it will hit the ground with less force that would be lethal to a human,” CEO Raptopoulos said.
“He hopes that similar operations will be conducted in U.S. airspace, and said the company is still evaluating whether such tests could be conducted under Part 107, with appropriate waivers” (https://www.aopa.org/news-and-media/all-news/2017/june/12/striving-for-flight-beyond-sight)  It’s appears that Matternet has more experience in flying drones than Amazon’s Prime Air. I cannot find details on Matternet’s safety record, though having a parachute onboard would be encouraging to the FAA in terms of receiving a waiver by proving operations could be conducted safely. The Matternet website also states: “Our technology has been certified by leading aviation authorities around the world including NASA and the Swiss Federal Office of Civil Aviation.” (https://mttr.net/product) 
If Matternet is still reviewing whether they would be granted a waiver, then the chance of a waiver being approved for Amazon is the same, if not less likely, as I haven’t found information on Amazons safety specs. Does anyone have any information on this?
With the current administration the likelihood is high unless Trump is insulted by something done by Amazon or the Wash Post and orders the FAA to deny permission.

Raising forecast: President Trump has announced his plan to privatise the air traffic control system. 
“Under the President’s plan, the FAA would focus solely on safety, while the airlines, passengers and general aviation would pay to create a non-profit company to more quickly introduce new satellite tracking technologies.” (http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-push-air-traffic-control-privatization-n768351) 
This proposed plan would likely encourage drones to be incorporated into the air traffic control system as there is money to be made. However, if the privatisation legislation is passed by congress, “it would take three years to transfer the existing US air traffic control system to the new non-profit entity” (http://uk.businessinsider.com/privatizing-air-traffic-control-for-drone-delivery-2017-6?r=US&IR=T). Which leads me to think that Amazon would not get a wavier this year.  However, reading through the remarks by the US Secretary of Transportation, Elaine Chao, at the ‘Drone Focus Conference’ have led me to increase my forecast:  “A key goal is to increase the capacity of our national airspace with the latest technology, so it can accommodate the expected increase in traffic as well as new entrants like drones.
“The department has launched an initiative to start answering questions, such as ‘how can we defend these systems from hackers’. The FAA has published more than 130 UAS facility maps to help streamline authorisations in the airspace around some of our busiest airports…The maps are informational. They do not give permission to fly drones. But the maps are an important step in making it easier and more routine to conduct “over the horizon” or “beyond line of sight” UAS operations.
“The FAA has also formed a new Aviation Rule making Committee, which will convene this summer to recommend technologies for remotely identifying and tracking unmanned aircraft during operations. The recommendations produced will help pave the way for increasingly complex drone flights, such as those over people and beyond visual line of sight operations.” 
(https://www.transportation.gov/briefing-room/drone-focus-conference?utm_source=Triggermail&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Post%20Blast%20%28bii-e-commerce%29:%20Privatizing%20air%20traffic%20control%20for%20drone%20delivery%20—%20Walmart%20tests%20grocery%20pickup%20automation%20—%20India%20is%20top%20country%20for%20retail%20investment&utm_term=BII%20List%20E-Comm%20ALL)  The steps that the U.S Department of Transportation and the FAA are taking, make it more likely that Amazon will get a waiver (as Amazon’s biggest hurdle is regulations), possibly towards the end of the year.

The "line of sight" requirement is reasonable, so FAA would not grant a waiver. Amazon could do its tests anywhere else in the world too, as they did in the UK. It is more likely that Amazon will roll out unmanned delivery service in the UK before doing it in the US, so we would wait for that news first. Also, drone delivery would not be the only way, nor the most efficient way. Aerial delivery would be useful in remote areas or rugged terrains, and visual line of sight is not hard to meet in those cases. Drone delivery in urban area would have to compete with autonomous truck/car/robot, since ground transportation is inherently more economical.

From websites listed below and just googling to read others, it seems like Amazon already received a waiver to test their UAV in the US.  If not, they've certainly flown UAVs as tests and are probably getting a waiver before 2018.

This might hamper Amazon's possibility of getting a waiver before a UAS traffic management system is in place: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/23/us/politics/drone-surveillance-policy.html?module=WatchingPortal&region=c-column-middle-span-region&pgType=Homepage&action=click&mediaId=thumb_square&state=standard&contentPlacement=12&version=internal&contentCollection=www.nytimes.com&contentId=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2017%2F05%2F23%2Fus%2Fpolitics%2Fdrone-surveillance-policy.html&eventName=Watching-article-click&_r=0

Raising forecast slightly:  Amazon has announced it has “started development of an air-traffic control system to manage its fleet as the drones fly from warehouses to customers’ doors.” 
When Paul Misener, Amazon’s vice president for global innovation policy and communications, was asked about when drones will be available to customers, he said “it will depend largely on government regulations and the company’s ability to prove its safe…We’re not going to launch this until we can demonstrate its safety”. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-18/amazon-s-delivery-drone-research-focuses-on-avoiding-birds) 
I’ve raised my forecast slightly based on this, as there is a possibility that with Amazon developing its own ATC it will be able to prove to the FAA that it is safe to use drones out of VLOS and therefore could warrant a waiver. Though this is dependent on how long it takes Amazon to set up a reasonably reliable ATC (looking towards the end of the year at least) and the location/s they propose to run tests - rural areas are obviously more favourable.  Also, worth noting Amazon is increasing its business in Australia which means it could start testing UAV’s there before the US. 
“Australia last year rolled out new rules for remote-operated drones, and government officials are looking to develop national guidelines for autonomous-vehicle trials.” (http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/05/17/welcome-to-jungle-amazons-australian-expedition-to-rattle-retailers.html)
New admin, who knows - are they going to be wanting to help WashPo Bezos? Or their trucking and oil mates?

Amazon has been pushing delivery drones for years and the public is expecting them. The FAA is open to this new technology for commercial purposes and under the new administration has pressure to make decisions in the best interest of commerce and economic gain. The red tape of bureaucracy, however, can still set this back.

Amazon is becoming a company that continually innovates. I believe they will find a way around the bureaucracy of the FAA.  The FAA hasn't been friendly do drones but Amazon will find a way at least in some markets to use drones.  Class B airspace may be exempt from the waiver until it's a proven technology, meaning they may not get to use the technology in the biggest markets, but medium size markets like Nashville might be available for testing.
It's complicated, and the current administration is more on the side of manual labor and less on advances in technology.

The FAA is under funded, under staffed and seemingly in turmoil. The current administration's desire to privatize air traffic control is at odds with the airlines and the FAA. I think this Amazon request is going to be highly politicized and used for multiple purposes, but the odds of them getting a green light for a rural test similar to what they're doing in the UK are still above average because if the FAA looks like it's thwarting business in the current climate, they'll ultimately be making the case against themselves when fighting those who want to privatize aspects of the agency.
Though they are on the outs with Trump, I doubt this will be important enough to become an issue. I believe they will allow the test.

Lowering forecast as Amazon is increasing its investment in drone delivery research in the UK (where has been testing deliveries). The fact that drone delivery research has largely moved out of the US due to the FAA not being very accommodating regarding testing has not so far persuaded the FAA to change its approach. I had assumed that the US would not want to fall too far behind is this field, but I guess if Amazon can do its testing abroad it does not need to fight to get a waiver to also test in the USA. 
https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/05/amazon-beefs-up-drone-delivery-rd-in-cambridge/
FAA has established no-fly zones and waiver for testing only -- much different than for actual commercial use.

Still not sure this is likely to happen this year, given the FAA won't change regulations anytime soon whilst they are testing a UAS Traffic Management system. 
Will change forecast once the FAA upload the details for the "standard special provisions for part 107 waivers" (https://www.faa.gov/uas/beyond_the_basics/#waiver) as this will be useful in determining whether amazon could be granted a waiver on the grounds that they can perform tests safely.

Decreasing from 100 % after no sign of Amazon waivers here https://www.faa.gov/uas/request_waiver/waivers_granted/ corresponding to their March demo flight https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/477319
Administrations have demonstrated some nice openness to autonomous systems, it is likely to happen around drones too.
I did research on commercial drones with the intent of publishing a paper.
Amazon is Big Business, I could see Trump being compensated to EO this through. He is squashing on the EPA for Big Oil, why not the FAA for Amazon?

The FAA has been very keen on the idea of maintaining line-of-sight during operations of drones.  Considering Amazon is headquartered in Seattle, it would have difficulty with the FAA granting it access to test their delivery beyond visual sight as Seattle is home to an international airport and various regional airports (I live here).  Additionally, Amazon has fulfillment centers in Illinois, Southern California, Dallas, etc. which are all homes to heavy air traffic.  If Amazon plans on deploying drones to delivery to their main customer base (out of each fulfillment center), it will not get cleared by the FAA to operate in the vicinity of airports.  25% chance as it currently stands.  The FAA is also very underfunded and understaffed.  When Section 333 exemptions were the lay of the land for drone operators, they were backlogged thousands of applications.  They aren't doing a very good job.

The White House released a 624 page document with new rules and regulations Tuesday pertaining to “the Commercial and Scientific Use of Drones,” and business leaders are already responding. “We simply don’t have the option of going through the traditional kind of five year time span in which we come up with regulatory outcomes and the standards,” Sean Cassidy, the director of strategic partnerships at Amazon Prime Air, the company’s conceptual drone-based delivery system, told The Washington Post in response to the new rules.
http://dailycaller.com/2016/06/21/business-leaders-unsurprisingly-tepid-about-faas-new-624-page-drone-rulebook/ Amazon’s Vice President for Global Public Policy, Paul Misener explains to Pogue that he hopes the United States is the first country to get drone delivery service, but that may not be the case:     “Well, we have customers all around the world, of course. There’s no reason why the United States must be first. We hope it is.” https://www.inverse.com/article/10330-amazon-drone-delivery-30-minutes-and-5-pound-limits-for-prime-air The agency mandated that Amazon's drones fly no higher than 122 m, no faster than 161 km/h, and remain within the pilot's line of sight. These rules are consistent with a proposed set of FAA guidelines. Ultimately, Amazon hopes to operate in a slice of airspace above 61 m and beneath 152 m.It plans to fly drones weighing a maximum of 25 kg within a 16 km radius of its warehouses, at speeds of up to 80.5 km/h with packages weighing up to 2.26 kg in tow[1]. [1]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Prime_Air Why Amazon is testing drone delivery in the U.K. — and not in the U.S.

There are some insightful comments from @flyn1200, @Raahul_Kumar and @mpuckette, much appreciated!  NASA’s website on Unmanned Traffic Management, a project conducted with the FAA, gives the following information about the test UTM TCL4, but to give it some context first: The “UTM TCL2, was completed in October 2016, leveraged TCL1 results and focused on beyond visual line-of-sight operations in sparsely populated areas. Researchers tested technologies that allowed dynamic adjustments to availability of airspace and contingency management” and “UTM TCL3, scheduled for January 2018, will leverage TCL2 results and focus on testing technologies that maintain safe spacing between cooperative (responsive) and non-cooperative (non-responsive) UAS over moderately populated areas.”
So, I think it is the most relevant to Amazon’s Prime Air as “UTM TCL4, with dates to be determined, will leverage TCL3 results and focus on UAS operations in higher-density urban areas for tasks such as news gathering and package delivery. It will also test technologies that could be used to manage large-scale contingencies.” 
I think the FAA will be relying on NASA’s project to complete all of their research before they change the regulations on UAV’s.  Amazons Prime Air plan differs from the other testing that is being carried out in the US by companies such as, 7-Eleven and UPS, as they all involve a line-of-sight rule. The UPS UAS project involves the driver of the vehicle piloting the drone to locations that are very rural/hard to access. Along with the issue of the law being that companies cannot fly drones out of visual line-of-sight, their main focus is what @mpuckette said about battery life. “When the UPS driver approached the intended home for delivery…she launched the drone from its roof. From there, the drone flew to the home based of a pre-programmed flight path, dropped off the package and then flew back to the van…the van’s roof opened and revealed a platform for the drone to land on, where it was able to plug itself into the battery charger.” (http://fortune.com/2017/02/21/ups-drone-deliveries-florida/). Though this concept involves drones, it is different to what Amazon is planning for, i.e. wanting to deliver directly from their depot to a customers location by autonomous flight, and explains why it’s been hard for them to get a certificate of waiver.  In the article from the guardian about Amazons Drone delivery project in the UK, it states: “Government regulations in the UK are generally considered favourable to companies wanting to experiment with autonomous aircraft, but restrictions still heavily limit what Amazon can test” (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/dec/14/amazon-claims-first-successful-prime-air-drone-delivery). Amazon was able to get approval to test in the UK before the US but was still confined by heavy restrictions, it seems that Amazon has a long way to go before they have the vision they are dreaming of up and running, especially in the US.  On Amazon's website they state: “Through our private trial in the UK, we will gather data to continue improving safety and reliability of our systems and operations ” (amazon.com), which leads me to ask the question that other forecasters have asked, will Amazon want to test their UAS’s in the USA before they are satisfied with their tests in the UK? They were only testing 2 customer locations, so if they take this approach, then we will be waiting a while before they test in the US.
Amazon will get the waiver if the FAA gets staffed!
The first drone use approval will help taken longer.

There is significant potential benefit associated with unmanned systems, and the FAA already allows similar unmanned vehicles for hobbyists, so it seems likely that authorization will happen eventually. The question I suspect is really how long it takes the FAA to decide they don't need visual line of sight.

Most waivers granted by the FAA are single waiver requests versus multiple item waiver requests. To be exact there have been 318 waivers granted for FAR 107. Only 7 waivers have had multiple FAR 107 waiver requests. Only 2.2% of FAR 107 waivers have had multiple FAR 107 line item waivers. The waiver for BNSF Railway is the closest multi-point waiver that could be compared to a Amazon waiver. But we must consider BNSF is not asking to operate over people, at night, and higher weight limits etc etc.  Considering this outside view of 2.2% I should have a much lower forecast for this GJO question right? But I am hung up on the decision makers and politics.

Granting a waiver is problematic for several reasons:  These drones are to be automated, not under the control of or monitored by a person, which is now the law.  The FAA is behind granting waivers to anyone for any reason because of the extremely rapid growth in requests; even search and rescue operations are waiting 90 days.  The technology is advancing so rapidly, any ruling on how to manage automation will already be inadequate in a year.  Plus, it may take a year of study to make a ruling on waivers for automated drones.  The Europeans have already developed and tested automated drone delivery; we know this works, but to do this on a commercial scale is hugely complex and costly. While the technology is well-developed, this isn't the hindrance.  It's airspace design and limitations, especially in urban areas, where drone delivery makes a lot of sense.  Corridors have been established, but because of use by general aviation aircraft and the separation distances they follow, drones could make these more dangerous. Rural airspace is not nearly so crowded or restricted, but distance becomes the problem. The very best batteries last at most an hour.  Depending on the weight of the delivery, this could be less.  That means a distant recipient would need to have a fresh battery on hand to replace in the drone for a return trip.  So if there's a rural drone "post office" where an employee handles this safely (and doesn't steal the drone), this is a cost to Amazon.  There are so many complexities to managing this. I could list many other challenges that the FAA would need to consider to assess the ramifications of a commercial drone operation.  People don't consider how much stuff is up there at typical drone altitudes: communications towers and their guy wires, power lines, birds, helicopters (which are allowed to fly at low altitudes most likely used by drones)... Automated drone delivery is such a cool idea, which is why there's so much interest is seeing it happen, but it's an operational nightmare.

The FAA have been making changes to airspace and navigation methods over the last several years. The class G airspace is disappearing, and class E and D are becoming more restricted. Densely populated areas are mostly class C or B. Having these drones flying through cities, avoiding controlled airspace will become an ATC nightmare.

The FAA reg Part 107 (linked in summary of question) says "Foreign-registered small unmanned aircraft are allowed to operate under part 107 if they satisfy the requirements of part 375." Part 375 seems to be here: http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?node=pt14.4.375#se14.4.375_12 I haven't read it closely but does it contemplate using e.g. a British certification to fly unmanned aircraft in the U.S.? [edit:/]the above-linked Part 375 appears to contemplate manned aircraft due the presence of a provision on AIrmen (see Part 375.21), which the FAA could arguably say shows drones are not covered by Part 375; on the other hand, the FAA expressly included reference to Part 375 in Part 107, which is about unmanned aircraft. [/edit:]

Maybe ones drones come with built-in anti-collision systems the FAA will give green light, unlikely to happen already in 2017.

Airspace in a populated area is a well regulated entity. The only airspace that is not heavily regulated is very low density population areas. In these areas, aircraft still fly. Additionally all aircraft are governed by rules. Given this, drone regulation would be difficult at best. The areas that drones would serve are also heavily populated. It is therefore an idea that would not be practical or conducive to ground based people and objects or aircraft.
Consistent with new administration's "easing of regulations" thrust. Waiver for testing-only is non-controversial.

It's just a waiver. Could come with all kinds of restrictions and may be extremely limited, such as to specific designated rural areas. Largest problem is the keyword "unmanned", but 7-Eleven got the waiver. https://www.faa.gov/uas/media/Part_107_Summary.pdf

So far the FAA has given lots of waivers but the vast majority are for waiving daylight use. Amazon is looking to waive the line of site requirement. I see few line of site waivers and they replace line of site for the operator with line of site for a visual observer. I am not sure if the FAA is ready to go as far as Amazon would like but the time frame is a year so it must be given some possibility.
Because of amazon project scale and the safety concern from the federal aviation Body, it will take much longer to get the ok on time.

FAA is partnered with NASA to create a "low altitude air traffic control" system for unmanned UAVs.  Publication date for a guideline is 2019.
Meanwhile, UPS, DHL, Amazon and DPD have reportedly moved testing to more regulatory friendly countries. Given the 1) strong support from business, 2) the need for the US to compete internationally for high tech development projects 3) the Republican administration, focused on reducing regulations that restrict business 4) FAA's desire to see standardized rules across the US; "waivers" for specific companies in specific areas seem a reasonable expectation.  Forcing companies to develop non-standard practices by placing technology development in a multitude of different countries with different rules, in the end will make US standardization that much more difficult.
Unless there is a major disaster of the Hindenburg type, this evolution is inevitable.
I'm a certified pilot and passed the drone test.  Amazon will never get a waiver.
Still a lot of issues with drone flight in and around urban areas, airports, and federal lands.  Contacts with aircraft are becoming more of an issue.
